The '''[[Colorado House of Representatives]] career of [[Douglas Bruce]]''' began with Bruce's appointment to a vacant legislative seat in November 2007 and his swearing-in in January 2008; he was a focal point of controversy during his one term in the state house, becoming the first legislator in Colorado history to be officially censured. He was defeated in the Republican primary in his 2008 bid for a full term.
==2007 House appointment== In October 2007, Bruce announced his plans to seek a seat in the [[Colorado House of Representatives]]. After Rep. [[Bill Cadman]] was appointed to fill a Senate seat vacated by [[Ron May (Colorado legislator)|Ron May]], Bruce sought to be appointed to Cadman's seat representing House District 15.<ref name="looking">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |title=A confident Bruce says he will seek appointment to house seat |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_28797___article.html/seat_county.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=October 23, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026014616/http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_28797___article.html/seat_county.html |archivedate=October 26, 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref name="opens">{{cite news |first=Tom |last=McGhee |title=Senate move opens House to TABOR author |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_28797___article.html/seat_county.html |work=Denver Post |date=November 4, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026014616/http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_28797___article.html/seat_county.html |archivedate=October 26, 2007 |df= }}</ref> Bruce faced two other Republican challengers for the appointment during a short but contentious battle for the vacancy committee nomination, during which he questioned the professional credentials of one of his opponents, and opponents charged that he was too divisive a figure to successfully represent the district. Ultimately, Bruce received two-thirds of the votes from the 66 members of the vacancy committee, beating out former school board candidate and engineer Reginald Perry and businessman Steve Hasbrouck.<ref name="wins">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |title=GOP chooses Bruce to fill House seat |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_30390___article_pluck.html/seat_vacancy.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=3 December 2007 |accessdate=2007-12-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071203181453/http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_30390___article_pluck.html/seat_vacancy.html |archivedate=3 December 2007 |df= }}</ref>
==2008 legislative session==
===Swearing-in controversy===
Bruce postponed being sworn in until January 14, 2008—several days after the start of the legislative session—in order to be eligible to serve a full four terms beyond the partial term under Colorado's [[term limits]] rules. The move was criticized by former Republican Senator Ron May and Democratic House Speaker [[Andrew Romanoff]],<ref name="late">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |title=Douglas Bruce plans a late start in house |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_30507___article.html/jan_seat.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=5 December 2007 |accessdate=2007-12-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524014053/http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_30507___article.html/jan_seat.html |archivedate=24 May 2011 |df= }}</ref> who, in response to Bruce's actions, called for legislation requiring that newly appointed legislators be sworn in within a specific period of time.<ref name="newlaw">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |title=Bruce’s late show may inspire new law |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_31059___article.html/romanoff_house.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=19 December 2007 |accessdate=2007-12-19 }}</ref> Such a bill, which would require appointed legislators to be sworn in within 14 days of their selection, was introduced later in the session by Democratic Reps. [[Paul Weissmann]] and [[Dorothy Butcher]];<ref name="swearingbill">{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Davidson |title=Bill aims to head off Bruce-like late shows |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/state_33394___article.html/weissmann_bill.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=22 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080328090655/http://www.gazette.com/articles/state_33394___article.html/weissmann_bill.html |archivedate=28 March 2008 |df= }}</ref> Bruce took the unusual step for a legislator of testifying against the bill at a committee hearing,<ref name="tread">{{cite news |first=Jennifer |last=Brown |title=Bruce: Don't tread on me |url=http://www.denverpost.com/headlines/ci_8483164 |work=Denver Post |date=7 March 2008 |accessdate=2008-03-07 }}</ref> but the bill passed the state house, with Bruce casting the only dissenting vote.<ref name="takeoff">{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Davidson |title=House OKs bill requiring legislators to take office within 14 days |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bill_35093___article.html/bruce_law.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=9 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080411055622/http://www.gazette.com/articles/bill_35093___article.html/bruce_law.html |archivedate=11 April 2008 |df= }}</ref>
Bruce clashed with legislative leaders over the time of his swearing-in, demanding to be sworn in at 10 a.m. in front of the full house. Both Speaker Romanoff and Republican leader [[Mike May (Colorado politician)|Mike May]] requested that Bruce take the oath at a different time, as is customary for vacancy appointments, in order not to interfere with House business.<ref name="disrupt">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |title=Bruce wants things his way |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/house_31855___article.html/bruce_romanoff.html |work=The Colorado Springs Gazette |date=12 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-01-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080115085415/http://www.gazette.com/articles/house_31855___article.html/bruce_romanoff.html |archivedate=15 January 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref name="demands">{{cite news |first=Alan |last=Gathright |title=Bruce demands audience for oath |url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/jan/12/bruce-demands-audience-for-oath/ |work=Rocky Mountain News |date=12 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-01-12 }}</ref> Bruce was present at the 10 a.m. start of legislative business on January 14, but he was not officially recognized by Speaker Romanoff during the morning session. After House Republicans voted 22-1 to call for a representative to be named for District 15 if Bruce did not take the oath of office by the end of the day, Bruce was sworn in by Romanoff at 1:30 p.m.<ref name="kicking">{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Barge |author2=Alan Gathright |title=Bruce alive and kicking in House |url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/jan/14/bruce-kicks-photographer/ |work=Rocky Mountain News |date=14 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-01-14 }}</ref>
Already fined for an unexcused absence from the commission meeting on Monday morning, Bruce submitted his resignation as an [[El Paso County, Colorado|El Paso County]] Commissioner after being sworn in as a state representative, effective January 15.<ref name="foot">{{cite news |first=Jennier |last=Brown |title=Kick helps get Bruce off on wrong foot with colleagues |url=http://www.denverpost.com/headlines/ci_7972150 |work=Denver Post |date=15 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-01-19 }}</ref> After his resignation, Bruce sent a letter to the vacancy committee members who would choose his replacement criticizing Amy Lathen, the leading candidate for his commission seat,<ref name="lathen">{{cite news |first=Carlyn Ray |last=Mitchell |title=GOP insiders say Lathen has edge |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/county_32070___article.html/lathen_seat.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=18 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-01-19 }}</ref> as unqualified and inconsistent on tax issues, calling her a "[[Republican in Name Only]];" the letter was denounced by El Paso County Republican Party officials.<ref name="riles">{{cite news |first=Carlyn Ray |last=Mitchell |title=Bruce riles GOP again, this time with a letter |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_32082___article.html/letter_lathen.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=18 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-01-19 }}</ref> Lathen, who had planned for months to run a primary campaign for the commission seat against Bruce, was elected by the vacancy committee with a majority of votes on the first ballot.<ref name="lathen2">{{cite news |first=R. Scott |last=Rappold |title=Lathen promises a different tone |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/lathen_32163___article.html/county_bruce.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=20 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-01-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080123172646/http://www.gazette.com/articles/lathen_32163___article.html/county_bruce.html |archivedate=23 January 2008 |df= }}</ref>
===Censure=== On the morning before he was sworn in, Bruce was present on the house floor during the session's morning prayer. Javier Manzano, a ''[[Rocky Mountain News]]'' photographer, took Bruce's picture during the prayer; Bruce kicked him in the knee, telling Manzano, "Do not do that again." Bruce later accused the photographer of "violating the order and decorum" of the house and refused to apologize. Republican Minority Leader Mike May issued a formal apology to the photographer, and state Republican chairman [[Dick Wadhams]] "strongly denounce[d]" Bruce's actions.<ref name="kicksup">{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Barge |title=House kicks up an investigation |url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/jan/15/this-isnt-over-leader-may-says/ |work=Rocky Mountain News |date=15 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-01-19 }}</ref>
Speaker Romanoff and Minority Leader May convened a bipartisan six-member panel to investigate and made recommendations concerning the incident;<ref name="panel">{{cite news |first=Jennifer |last=Brown |title=House panel steps into kicking incident |url=http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_7980951 |work=Denver Post |date=16 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-01-19 }}</ref> on Friday, January 18, the panel recommended 6-0 that Bruce be censured by the House for his actions, and 5-1 that a formal apology be requested from Bruce.<ref name="chides">{{cite news |first=Jennifer |last=Brown |title=House panel chides Bruce over kick |url=http://origin.denverpost.com/rapids/ci_8010233?_requestid=1919337 |work=Denver Post |date=18 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-01-19 }}</ref> Although Manzano testified before the panel, he declined to press criminal charges against Bruce.
Romanoff elected to pursue the censure recommendation, and, on January 24, the full House of Representatives voted 62-1 (with only Rep. [[Kevin Lundberg]] opposed) to censure Bruce. He became the first representative in the recorded history of the state house to be formally censured.<ref name="censure">{{cite news |author=Staff Reports |title=House censures Douglas Bruce |url=http://www.denverpost.com/rapids/ci_8066076 |work=Denver Post |date=24 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-01-24 }}</ref>
===Legislative agenda=== {{Infobox Colorado Legislation |Title=Rep. |Name=Bruce |Year=2008 |Bill Number 1=HB08-1145 |Bill Number 2=HB08-1245 |Bill Number 3=HB08-1277 |Bill Number 4=HB08-1279 |Bill Link 1=http://www.leg.state.co.us/clics/clics2008a/csl.nsf/fsbillcont/9D0E81896FDAB9DE872573AA00569BFB?Open&file=1145_01.pdf |Bill Link 2=http://www.leg.state.co.us/clics/clics2008a/csl.nsf/fsbillcont/A8DBA94A11400B4B872573A80077EEFC?Open&file=1245_01.pdf |Bill Link 3=http://www.leg.state.co.us/clics/clics2008a/csl.nsf/fsbillcont/60B8D8BE5FF1FD85872573D1006D24D2?Open&file=1277_01.pdf |Bill Link 4=http://www.leg.state.co.us/clics/clics2008a/csl.nsf/fsbillcont/D51924CD12A8D744872573D100562AEE?Open&file=1279_01.pdf |Bill Status 1=Postponed indefinitely in House committee |Bill Status 2=Postponed indefinitely in House committee |Bill Status 3=Postponed indefinitely in House committee |Bill Status 4=Postponed indefinitely in House committee |Bill Title 1=Concerning education on fundamental civic documents. |Bill Title 2=Concerning required reductions in specified government-imposed means of raising revenue. |Bill Title 3=Concerning the prohibition of improper uses of property to enforce collections. |Bill Title 4=Concerning governmental land use regulations [...] }}
For the 2008 session of the Colorado General Assembly, Bruce was named to seats on the House Finance Committee and the House State, Veterans, and Military Affairs Committee.<ref name="cmte2008">{{cite web |url=http://www.leg.state.co.us/clics/clics2008a/directory.nsf/HouCommWp?OpenView |title=House Committees of Reference |accessdate=2008-01-19 |work=Colorado General Assembly}}</ref> At the start of the 2008 General Assembly session, before being sworn in, Bruce announced his opposition to a large portion of the House Republican caucus legislative agenda, including a [[sales tax holiday]] for school supplies, a [[pine beetle]] mitigation fund, new specialty [[license plates]], and targeted [[tax credits]], noting in a letter to Republican [[whip]] [[Cory Gardner]]: "I thought the GOP was the party of less government and more freedom, of protecting individualism, not streamlining socialism."<ref name="nonono">{{cite news |first=Cara |last=DeGette |title=Douglas Bruce's Message To His Party: No! No! No! |url=http://www.coloradoconfidential.com/showDiary.do?diaryId=3322 |work=Colorado Confidential |date=11 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-01-19 }}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The first bill introduced by Bruce during the 2008 session was a measure to require the Colorado Department of Education to distribute copies of the [[United States Declaration of Independence|Declaration of Independence]] and [[U.S. Constitution]] to high school seniors, to mandate classroom instruction on the documents,<ref name="declar">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |title=Assembly Glance: Thursday in review |url=http://origin.denverpost.com/rapids/ci_8010233?_requestid=1919337 |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=18 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-01-19 }}l</ref> and to offer a brief [[constitutional law]] course to members of the [[Colorado General Assembly]].<ref name="school">{{cite news|first=Mike |last=Saccone |title=Bruce wants colleagues schooled |url=http://www.gjsentinel.com/news/content/news/stories/2008/01/20/012108_3A_Bruce_bill.html |work=Grand Junction Daily Sentinel |date=20 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-01-23 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The bill died after facing unanimous opposition from the House Education Committee.<ref name="glance">{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Davidson |author2=Ed Sealover |title=Assembly glance |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bill_32621___article.html/house_state.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=1 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524010947/http://www.gazette.com/articles/bill_32621___article.html/house_state.html |archivedate=24 May 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Another of Bruce's bills, which would have prohibited counties from assessing any charges other than property taxes, including fines for delinquent payments or stormwater fees, on property tax bills, was also killed in committee.<ref name="tuesday">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |author2=Michael Davidson |title=Tuesday in the General Assembly |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/tax_33336___article.html/colorado_bruce.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=19 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524014148/http://www.gazette.com/articles/tax_33336___article.html/colorado_bruce.html |archivedate=24 May 2011 |df= }}</ref> Bruce also advanced a measure which would have eliminated ''[[per diem]]'' expense payments for legislators and indexed legislators' pay to inflation, as well as requiring voter approval for any pay increases above this amount.<ref name="limit">{{cite news|author=Associated Press |title=Colo. Plan Would Limit Lawmaker Pay |url=http://www.portfolio.com/news-markets/national-news/ap/2008/02/22/colo-plan-would-limit-lawmaker-pay |work=Conde Nast Portfolio.com |date=22 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-23 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> All four bills introduced by Bruce were killed in committee.<ref name="pariah">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |title=Douglas Bruce: A pariah or a beleaguered reformer? |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_33745___article.html/committee_waller.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=1 March 2008 |accessdate=2008-03-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080304005655/http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_33745___article.html/committee_waller.html |archivedate=4 March 2008 |df= }}</ref> Late in the legislative session, Bruce introduced a bill to create a seven-member bipartisan panel, including three unaffiliated voters, to draw up Colorado's congressional and legislative districts following the [[2010 United States Census|2010 census]] and [[reapportionment]].<ref name="bills2">{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Davidson |title=2 bills seek to change how Colorado's electoral districts are drawn |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/gordon_34721___article.html/party_voters.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=28 March 2008 |accessdate=2008-03-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080401004337/http://www.gazette.com/articles/gordon_34721___article.html/party_voters.html |archivedate=1 April 2008 |df= }}</ref>
Bruce has also objected to the practice of attaching a "safety clause" to bills, a provision which uses a declaration that the bill is "necessary for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health or safety" to change the date of enactment and prohibit challenges to the legislation via the petition process. He has pledged to vote against all legislation containing an unjustified safety clause,<ref name="safety">{{cite news |author=Staff Reports |title=Bruce rips legislation's "safety clause." |url=http://www.denverpost.com/headlines/ci_7981831 |work=Denver Post |date=16 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-15 }}</ref> and has offered amendments to a number of bills to remove the safety clause.<ref name="venerable">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |title=Venerable "safety clause" an early Bruce target |url=http://daily.gazette.com/Repository/ml.asp?Ref=VGhlR2F6ZXR0ZS8yMDA4LzAxLzE2I0FyMDA4MDI=&Mode=HTML&Locale=english-skin-custom |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=16 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-15 }}</ref> Bruce's amendments often failed on account of legislators' personal hostility towards him; on at least one occasion, after the house voted down his proposal to strike the safety clause, the motion passed after being introduced by another legislator.<ref name="pariah"/> House members eventually developed the practice of supporting the removal of the safety clause if the legislator sponsoring the bill agreed; in 2008, 41% of bill passed had no safety clause, up from 25% the previous year.<ref name="smallchange">{{cite news|first=Joe |last=Hanel |title=Bruce wins small changes on "safety clause" |url=http://durangoherald.com/asp-bin/article_generation.asp?article_type=news&article_path=/news/08/news080628_6.htm |work=Durango Herald |date=28 June 2008 |accessdate=2008-07-20 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
Bruce also proposed several changes to House operations and procedure, including use of [[taser]]s by state capitol security—a proposal received favorably by legislative leaders<ref name="taser">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |title=Bruce plan for Tasers welcomed; request for bigger office isn't |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_34140___article.html/office_capitol.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=12 March 2008 |accessdate=2008-03-17 }}</ref>—and increased office space for legislators—an idea not well received.<ref name="offspace">{{cite news |author=Staff Reports |title=Roll call, March 13 |url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/mar/13/roll-call-march-13/ |work=Rocky Mountain News |date=13 March 2008 |accessdate=2008-03-17 }}</ref>
Bruce was a vocal critic of the proposed state budget debated during the 2008 legislative session,<ref name="rollcalldom">{{cite news |author=Staff Reports |title=Roll call, March 27 |url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/mar/27/roll-call-march-27/ |work=Rocky Mountain News |date=27 March 2008 |accessdate=2008-03-28 }}</ref> characterizing the budget's $3,500 in expenditures per Colorado resident as "fiscal child abuse."<ref name="passes">{{cite news|first=Joe |last=Hanel |title=State’s $17.6B budget passes House |url=http://durangoherald.com/asp-bin/article_generation.asp?article_type=news&article_path=/news/08/news080328_1.htm |work=Durango Herald |date=28 March 2008 |accessdate=2008-03-28 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref name="child">{{cite news |author=Staff Reports |title=GOP rolls eyes as House Dems cite kids in budget nod |url=http://www.denverpost.com/politics/ci_8723241 |work=Denver Post |date=28 March 2008 |accessdate=2008-03-28 }}</ref> During budget debates, Bruce offered unsuccessful amendments to eliminate 524 new employees at colleges and universities, to cut a federally funded program for prevention of [[sexually transmitted diseases]],<ref name="brucecut">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |title=House Dems thwart GOP efforts to pare down state budget |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/state_34631___article.html/budget_workers.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=26 March 2008 |accessdate=2008-03-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080328162739/http://www.gazette.com/articles/state_34631___article.html/budget_workers.html |archivedate=28 March 2008 |df= }}</ref> and to prevent the transfer of 165 contract corrections employees to state payrolls.<ref name="takesup">{{cite news |first=Jane |last=Slater |title=House Takes Up State's Budget |url=http://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/15714444/detail.html |work=TheDenverChannel.com |date=26 March 2008 |accessdate=2008-03-28 }}</ref>
Bruce also joined with left-leaning and environmental groups in opposing proposed changes to Colorado's petition process that would raise signature requirements and make it more difficult to put proposals to amend the Colorado state constitution on the statewide ballot.<ref name="tougher">{{cite news|first=Joe |last=Hanel |title=Panel: Make it tougher to amend constitution |url=http://durangoherald.com/asp-bin/article_generation.asp?article_type=news&article_path=/news/08/news080410_7.htm |work=Durango Herald |date=10 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-11 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref name="libbruce">{{cite news|first=Joe |last=Hanel |title=Liberal groups, Bruce join forces |url=http://durangoherald.com/asp-bin/article_generation.asp?article_type=news&article_path=/news/08/news080502_4.htm |work=Durango Herald |date=2 May 2008 |accessdate=2008-05-02 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
Bruce also entered into debate on, and voted against, a bill to impose new requirements on [[landlord]]s and set standards for rental properties. His actions generated criticism from other legislators, who argued that Bruce should have recused himself from voting on the measure because his ownership of rental properties created a [[conflict of interest]]; two other legislators recused themselves for similar reasons.<ref name="tenant">{{cite news |first=Tim |last=Hoover |title=House gives initial OK to bill on tenant rights |url=http://www.denverpost.com/headlines/ci_9031511 |work=Denver Post |date=24 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-24 }}</ref><ref name="defendst">{{cite news |author=Staff Reports |title=Bruce Defends Voting On Landlord-Tenant Bill |url=http://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/15983568/detail.html |work=TheDenverChannel.com |date=24 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-24 }}</ref>
===Removal from committee=== On February 13, Bruce, alone among 100 state legislators, refused to sign on as a cosponsor to an annual joint resolution recognizing [[Military and Veterans Appreciation Day]]. Bruce had protested other resolutions in the legislature as a waste of time,<ref name="snubs">{{cite news |first=Alan |last=Gathright |author2=Daniel J. Chacon |title=Bruce snubs military tribute |url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/feb/13/bruce-votes-no-vets/ |work=Rocky Mountain News |date=13 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-15 }}</ref> similar to his practice of refusing to vote on resolutions as an El Paso County commissioner.<ref name="riles2">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |title=Bruce riles GOP over veterans resolution |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_33094___article.html/veterans_resolution.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=14 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080220001908/http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_33094___article.html/veterans_resolution.html |archivedate=20 February 2008 |df= }}</ref> Later in the session, Bruce proposed a change to House rules to allow members to abstain from voting on resolutions.<ref name="view2">{{cite news |author=Editorial Board |title=Our View - Friday |url=http://www.gazette.com/opinion/tax_34208___article.html/increase_colorado.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=13 March 2008 |accessdate=2008-03-17 }}</ref>
In response to public complaints, Republican Minority Leader Mike May removed Bruce from the House State, Veterans and Military Affairs Committee, which oversees veterans' issues. Bruce dismissed the move as "political posturing."<ref name="tossed">{{cite news |first=Daniel J. |last=Chacon |title=Rep. Bruce tossed off panel |url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/feb/15/bruce-tossed-panel/ |work=Rocky Mountain News |date=15 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-15 }}</ref> Other Republican legislators denounced Bruce in a public letter for "callous indifference" towards veterans.<ref name="honor">{{cite news|first=Marshall |last=Zelinger |title=Rep. Doug Bruce Refuses To Honor Military |url=http://www.krdo.com/Global/story.asp?S=7870154 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220063051/http://www.krdo.com/Global/story.asp?S=7870154 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=20 December 2016 |work=KRDO.com |date=13 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-15 }}</ref> Bruce offered as evidence of his support for veterans his successful amendment to a house bill to include interest in a state repayment to the Colorado Veterans Trust Fund, a move which resulted in an additional $636,000 repaid to the fund.<ref name="yanked">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |author2=Michael Davidson |title=Bruce yanked off veterans committee |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_33171___article.html/veterans_committee.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=15 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080219191627/http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_33171___article.html/veterans_committee.html |archivedate=19 February 2008 |df= }}</ref> Bruce would later cite this as one of his major accomplishments during the 2008 session.<ref name="pariah"/>
The following week, Bruce signed on as a cosponsor to an annual resolution calling for civility between members of the legislature; he said that it did not violate his standard of refusing to support symbolic resolutions because he considered the measure to be a "pledge of personal behavior."<ref name="civil">{{cite news |author=Staff Reports | title=House resolves to be civil, Bruce votes aye |url=http://www.denverpost.com/lacrosse/ci_8304878 |work=Denver Post |date=19 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-23 }}</ref>
===Per diem controversy=== As a legislator, Bruce was entitled to apply for ''[[per diem]]'' compensation for living expenses during the legislative session. After having delayed his swearing into the state house for five days after the start of the session, Bruce applied for and received compensation for those days amounting to $750 more than what he was legally entitled to. Colorado legislative council staff later accepted responsibility for what was referred to as a "clerical error"<ref name="perk">{{cite news |first=Jessica |last=Fender | title=It's all in a day's perk: wrangling over per diems |url=http://www.denverpost.com/headlines/ci_8318937 |work=Denver Post |date=22 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-23 }}</ref><ref name="overch">{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Barge | title=Douglas Bruce overcharges state on per diem |url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/feb/20/douglas-bruce-overcharges-state-diem/ |work=Rocky Mountain News |date=20 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-23 }}</ref> and has pledged to return the excess funds.<ref name="return">{{cite news |author=Associated Press |title=Douglas Bruce claims too much in expenses, says he'll return money |url=http://www.greeleytrib.com/article/20080221/NEWS/271451441 |work=Greeley Tribune |date=21 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-03-01 }}</ref> Bruce has pledged to donate his legislative salary and ''per diem'' payments to the non-profit charity "Active Citizens Together,"<ref name="act">{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Barge | title=Bruce: $750 overcharge an error |url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/feb/21/bruce-overcharges-750-cites-error/ |work=Rocky Mountain News |date=21 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-23 }}</ref> a group founded by Bruce to educate citizens on personal and property rights<ref name="over">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover | title=Bruce asks state for $750 too much |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_33361___article.html/days_office.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=21 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-23 }}</ref> and advocate for limited government.<ref name="irony">{{cite news |first=Cara |last=DeGette |title=The Irony Of The Bruce Anti-Tax Machine |url=http://www.coloradoconfidential.com/showDiary.do?diaryId=3484 |work=Colorado Confidential |date=23 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-03-01 }}</ref>
==="Illiterate peasants" comments=== On April 21, 2008, Bruce voiced opposition during house debate on a bill sponsored by Rep. [[Marsha Looper]] to create a [[guest worker program]] to facilitate temporary employment visas for agricultural workers from Mexico. After speaking against [[illegal immigration]] and being advised to restrict comments to the bill by debate chair Rep. [[Kathleen Curry]], Bruce took the floor a second time and commented: {{quote|I would like to have the opportunity to state at the microphone why I don't think we need 5,000 more illiterate peasants in Colorado.}}
Bruce was immediately [[gavel]]led to order by Rep. Curry, who ruled that he would no longer be recognized during debate on the bill.<ref name="peasants">{{cite news |author=Staff Reports |title=Bruce: Illegal immigrant workers are 'illiterate peasants' |url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/apr/21/bruce-mexican-workers-are-illiterate-peasants/ |work=Rocky Mountain News |date=21 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-21 }}</ref><ref name="rebukes">{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Barge |author2=Alan Gathright |title=Rebukes envelop Bruce |url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/apr/21/bruce-mexican-workers-are-illiterate-peasants/ |work=Rocky Mountain News |date=21 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-29 }}</ref> Bruce's comments were denounced by Assistant Majority Leader [[Terrance Carroll]] as violating the "decorum of the house;" they were also criticized by Minority Leader Mike May,<ref name="farmwork">{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Davidson |title=Bruce calls farmworkers 'illiterate peasants' |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/workers_35510___article.html/bruce_rep.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=21 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080424122104/http://www.gazette.com/articles/workers_35510___article.html/bruce_rep.html |archivedate=24 April 2008 |df= }}</ref> the Mexican consulate in [[Denver, Colorado|Denver]].<ref name="removed"/> and the [[Anti-Defamation League]].<ref name="adl">{{cite press release | title=ADL Decries Rep. Bruce Comments Calling Foreign Workers 'Illiterate Peasants' |publisher=Anti-Defamation League | date=22 April 2008 |url=http://www.adl.org/PresRele/DiRaB_41/5274_41.htm | accessdate=2008-04-23 }}</ref> The following day, the Latino Faith-Based Initiative, and the Democratic Party Latino Initiative both called for Bruce's resignation from the legislature.<ref name="resign">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |title=Critics call for Bruce's resignation after remark |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_35551___article.html/colorado_rep.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=22 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-22 }}</ref>
Bruce defended his remarks as being factually accurate, citing dictionary definitions of "illiterate" and "peasant". Legislators briefly considered bringing a formal ethics complaint against him,<ref name="removed">{{cite news |first=Steven K. |last=Paulson |title=Colo. lawmaker removed from podium over Mexicans remark |url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5gjejGz2ScBlo-Eccugkvp2u9HLZQD906JKB00 |work=Associated Press |date=21 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080504235016/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5gjejGz2ScBlo-Eccugkvp2u9HLZQD906JKB00 |archivedate=4 May 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref name="barred">{{cite news |first=Jessica |last=Fender |title=Bruce barred from speaking after 'illiterate' remark |url=http://origin.denverpost.com/rapids/ci_9003612 |work=Denver Post |date=21 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-21 }}</ref> but ultimately chose not to. Legislators responded to Bruce's propensity for generating controversy by declaring that they would "start ignoring him".<ref name="noprobe">{{cite news |first=Tim |last=Hoover |title=No ethics probe for Bruce over Mexican comment |url=http://origin.denverpost.com/headlines/ci_9014237 |work=Denver Post |date=22 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-22 }}</ref><ref name="wake">{{cite news |first=Charlie |last=Brennan |title=Threats in Wake of Bruce Controversy |url=http://www.myfoxcolorado.com/myfox/pages/News/Detail?contentId=6379598&version=1&locale=EN-US&layoutCode=TSTY&pageId=3.2.1 |work=MyFoxColorado |date=23 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-26 }}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Rep. Curry requested additional law enforcement protection after receiving an influx of threatening messages from opponents of [[illegal immigration]].<ref name="threat">{{cite news|first=Mike |last=Saccone |title=Legislator threatened over Bruce incident |url=http://www.gjsentinel.com/news/content/news/stories/2008/04/22/042308_1a_Curry.html |work=Grand Junction Sentinel |date=22 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-23 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080527165721/http://www.gjsentinel.com/news/content/news/stories/2008/04/22/042308_1a_Curry.html |archivedate=2008-05-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Bruce, however, received hundreds of largely positive email messages in response to news coverage of the controversy.<ref name="brigade">{{cite news |first=John |last=Ingold |title=Brigade of Bruce defenders fires e-mail barrage |url=http://www.denverpost.com/politics/ci_9031798 |work=Denver Post |date=24 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-24 }}</ref><ref name="glance3">{{cite news|first=Michael |last=Davidson |title=Legislative glance: Wednesday in Review |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/fallout_35607___article.html/glance_legislative.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=24 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524015346/http://www.gazette.com/articles/fallout_35607___article.html/glance_legislative.html |archivedate=2011-05-24 |df= }}</ref> The following weekend, Bruce's comments were the target of a local protest in Colorado Springs attended by about 50.<ref name="quote">{{cite news |first=Annette |last=Espinoza |title=Bruce quote sparks protest |url=http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_9068166 |work=Denver Post |date=27 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-27 }}</ref><ref name="migrant">{{cite news |first=Terry |last=Jessup |title=Migrant Workers Protest Bruce's 'Peasant' Comments |url=http://cbs4denver.com/local/bruce.migrant.workers.2.706714.html |work=CBS4Denver.com |date=27 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080506085110/http://cbs4denver.com/local/bruce.migrant.workers.2.706714.html |archivedate=6 May 2008 |df= }}</ref>
Several days later, Bruce submitted an amendment — facetiously drafted by the "linguistic sensitivity codification commission" — to another bill addressing immigration issues to substitute "undocumented, temporary guest resident" in place of "illegal aliens" in statutory language. The amendment was offered and defeated twice.<ref name="pc">{{cite news |first=Jessica |last=Fender |title=A new, improved and PC Bruce |url=http://www.politicswest.com/23776/new_improved_and_pc_bruce |work=Denver Post |date=25 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-25 }}</ref><ref name="sensitive">{{cite news |first=Jeremy |last=Pelzer |title=Bruce shows his sensitive side |url=http://www.politickerco.com/jeremypelzer/1006/bruce-shows-his-sensitive-side |work=PolitickerCO |date=25 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-25 }}</ref>
===Sexual harassment complaint=== On April 30, Bruce was the subject of a sexual harassment complaint after a female legislative staffer alleged that he made inappropriate verbal comments towards her. After being formally confronted by House Speaker [[Andrew Romanoff]], Bruce was instructed to stay away from the woman who filed the complaint, according to reports by other representatives.<ref name="complaint">{{cite news |first=Lynn |last=Bartels |title=Woman files sexual harassment complaint against embattled Bruce |url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/apr/30/female-staffer-lodges-complaint-against-bruce/ |work=Rocky Mountain News |date=30 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-30 }}</ref><ref name="files">{{cite news |first=Adam |last=Schrager |title=Bruce accused of sexually harassing staffer |url=http://www.9news.com/news/top-article.aspx?storyid=90954 |work=9News.com |date=30 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-30 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref name="accuses">{{cite news |first=Jessica |last=Fender |title=Sources: Staffer accuses Bruce of sex harassment |url=http://www.denverpost.com/commented/ci_9114126?source=commented-news |work=Denver Post |date=1 May 2008 |accessdate=2008-05-01 }}</ref> Legislative leaders refused to publicly discuss the complaint,<ref name="complaint2">{{cite news |first=Jessica |last=Fender |title=Complaint against Rep. Bruce still unclear |url=http://www.denverpost.com/headlines/ci_9125801 |work=Denver Post |date=2 May 2008 |accessdate=2008-05-02 }}</ref> but Douglas Bruce stated in a radio interview that the incident in question involved only looking and smiling at a woman.<ref name="justlook">{{cite news |author=Staff Reports |title=Bruce says he "just looked" at woman |url=http://www.denverpost.com/ci_9136176 |work=Denver Post |date=2 May 2008 |accessdate=2008-05-03 }}</ref>
After both Bruce and the woman involved were interviewed by attorneys,<ref name="complaint3">{{cite news |first=Brian |last=Newsome |title=Bruce cleared of sexual harassment |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_38455___article.html/woman_complaint.html |work=Denver Post |date=21 July 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-08 }}</ref> Bruce reported in July that the harassment complaint had been dismissed for lack of evidence,<ref name="dismissed">{{cite news |first=Jessica |last=Fender |title=Harassment complaint dismissed, Bruce says |url=http://www.denverpost.com/headlines/ci_9943785 |work=Denver Post |date=21 July 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-08 }}</ref> and suggested that the timing of the investigation's conclusion was politically motivated, coming just weeks before a contested primary race.<ref name="conspir">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |title=State Rep. Bruce smells a conspiracy |url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/jul/22/state-rep-bruce-smells-a-conspiracy/ |work=Rocky Mountain News |date=22 July 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-08 }}</ref>
==2008 election== Bruce announced in November 2007 that he would stand in the 2008 general election for the House District 15 seat.<ref name="among">{{cite news |first=Julia C. |last=Martinez |title=Douglas Bruce among three vying for House seat |url=http://blogs.denverpost.com/opinion/2007/11/27/douglas-bruce-among-three-vying-for-house-seat/ |work=Denver Post |date=November 27, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-27 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080101124849/http://blogs.denverpost.com/opinion/2007/11/27/douglas-bruce-among-three-vying-for-house-seat/ |archivedate=2008-01-01 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> He faces a challenge for the Republican nomination from attorney and [[Iraq War]] veteran Mark Waller.<ref name="wins"/> Following the precedent of his county commission campaign four years earlier, Bruce funded his own campaign, refusing to accept private campaign donations;<ref name="polgab">{{cite news |first=Pam |last=Zubeck |title=POLITIGAB: Bruce says no to dependency |url=http://www.gazette.com/news/parade_37868___article.html/crank_district.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=2 July 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524020206/http://www.gazette.com/news/parade_37868___article.html/crank_district.html |archivedate=24 May 2011 |df= }}</ref> instead, Bruce donated over $30,000 of his own money to his campaign.<ref name="thous">{{cite news |first=Perry |last=Swanson |title=POLITIGAB: Thousands spent in primary runs |url=http://www.gazette.com/news/candidates_39058___article.html/state_primary.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=7 August 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110524043205/http://www.gazette.com/news/candidates_39058___article.html/state_primary.html |archivedate=24 May 2011 |df= }}</ref> He did, however, unsuccessfully solicit donations for his charity, Active Citizens Together, from other lawmakers.<ref name="strife">{{cite news |first=Tim |last=Hoover |title=Bruce's rival says strife fails voters |url=http://www.denverpost.com/headlines/ci_9963889 |work=Denver Post |date=22 July 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-08 }}</ref> Reflecting Bruce's status as a "pariah" among some Colorado Springs Republicans,<ref name="pariah"/> Waller received endorsements or contributions during his campaign from at least five sitting state representatives, including [[Bob Gardner]],{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} [[Larry Liston]],<ref name="pariah"/> and [[Marsha Looper]],<ref name="thous"/> as well as former Sen. [[Ron May (Colorado legislator)|Ron May]]<ref name="trail">{{cite news |author=Staff Reports |title=On the stump - February 29, 2008 |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/waller_33740___article.html/district_business.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=29 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-03-02 }}</ref> and Colorado Attorney General [[John Suthers]].{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
Waller outpolled Bruce by receiving 57% of the vote at the Republican assembly in March, claiming the top line on the August Republican primary ballot;<ref name="no2">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |title=Bruce knocked to No. 2 on the ballot |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_33993___article.html/waller_saturday.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=8 March 2008 |accessdate=2008-03-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080310224207/http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_33993___article.html/waller_saturday.html |archivedate=10 March 2008 |df= }}</ref> he was supported by some delegates who had voted for Bruce's legislative appointment months earlier.<ref name="werewrong">{{cite news |first=Cara |last=DeGette |title=Former Douglas Bruce Supporter: 'We Were Wrong' |url=http://coloradoconfidential.com/showDiary.do;jsessionid=4D722AE30C0FD392D188670110FA2D33?diaryId=3644 |work=Colorado Confidential |date=5 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-22 }}</ref><ref name="lipsink"/> During his campaign, Waller did not draw a contrast on political positions with Bruce, but argued that Bruce's temperament caused him to be an ineffective legislator.<ref name="toughrace">{{cite news |first=Perry |last=Swanson |title=Waller has a tough fight in race with Douglas Bruce |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/tough_38171___article.html/waller_bruce.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=12 July 2007 |accessdate=2008-08-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524020508/http://www.gazette.com/articles/tough_38171___article.html/waller_bruce.html |archivedate=24 May 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Bruce faced criticism from House Democratic and Republican leaders in April for distributing campaign fliers critical of Waller to Republican representatives on the House floor. Although not a violation of the law or House rules, legislative leaders denounced the action as a breach of decorum and tradition.<ref name="fire">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |title=Bruce draws fire over fliers |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_34830___article.html/house_fliers.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=1 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524020632/http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_34830___article.html/house_fliers.html |archivedate=24 May 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref name="rebuke">{{cite news |first=John |last=Ingold |author2=Jessica Fender |title=Bruce fliers bring rebuke |url=http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_8774429 |work=Denver Post |date=1 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-02 }}</ref> Waller also called for Bruce's resignation in April 2008, after Bruce's controversial comments about Mexican guest workers.<ref name="noprobe"/> Bruce, in response, characterised Waller as a "conformer" rather than a "reformer," and stated that his controversial actions were designed to draw attention to inappropriate legislative actions.<ref name="lipsink">{{cite news |first=Karen E. |last=Crummy |title=Bruce's lip sinking his ship? |url=http://www.denverpost.com/search/ci_9099564 |work=Denver Post |date=30 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-30 }}</ref>
Shortly before the August primary, Bruce was again criticized by Waller for mailing flyers promoting his charity, Active Citizens Together, soliciting volunteers and donations for the charity and stating: "to reform government, ACT with Douglas Bruce." Although Waller declared that the flyers were "an obvious attempt at campaigning," he did not file a complaint with the [[Colorado Secretary of State]]'s office, as he believed no laws were actually broken; the flyers did not mention any of Bruce's elected positions.<ref name="jugular">{{cite news |first=Pam |last=Zubeck |title=Politigab: Jeff Crank launches another radio ad |url=http://www.gazette.com/news/bruce_38016___article_news.html/waller_act.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=8 July 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130124172108/http://www.gazette.com/news/bruce_38016___article_news.html/waller_act.html |archivedate=24 January 2013 |df= }}</ref> Bruce was also criticized for listing endorsements on his website from political officials who had endorsed his campaign for county commissioner, but not specifically endorsed his legislative campaign. After attention was called to the discrepancy, Bruce had the erroneous endorsements removed, citing an "overzealous webmaster."<ref name="sayendor">{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Sealover |title=Backers named on Bruce Web site say endorsement from 2004 |url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/jul/21/backers-named-bruce-web-site-say-endorsement-2004/ |work=Rocky Mountain News |date=21 July 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-08 }}</ref>
In turn, Bruce filed several campaign finance complaints against Waller, all but one of which—an accusation that Waller improperly accepted a corporate donation—were dismissed.<ref name="faceoff"/> The hearing on Bruce's complaint was postponed until after the primary, over Bruce's objection, but resulted in Waller being cited and fined for failing to disclose a campaign contribution.<ref name="failing">{{cite news |first=Perry |last=Swanson |title=Waller campaign fined for failing to report funds |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/waller_40196___article.html/campaign_schuck.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=4 September 2008 |accessdate=2008-09-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120606140434/http://www.gazette.com/articles/waller_40196___article.html/campaign_schuck.html |archivedate=6 June 2012 |df= }}</ref> Bruce also criticized Waller for his failure to vote in several recent elections, including the 2004 general election.<ref name="faceoff">{{cite news |first=Perry |last=Swanson |title=Bruce, Waller face off |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/face_38692___article.html/republican_candidates.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=27 July 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524020810/http://www.gazette.com/articles/face_38692___article.html/republican_candidates.html |archivedate=24 May 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Bruce was narrowly defeated for the Republican nomination in the August 12 party primary, taking only 48 percent of the vote to Waller's 52 percent.<ref name="defeats">{{cite news |first=Perry |last=Swanson |title=Waller defeats Bruce |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_39268___article_news.html/waller_republican.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=12 August 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130124002040/http://www.gazette.com/articles/bruce_39268___article_news.html/waller_republican.html |archivedate=24 January 2013 |df= }}</ref>
Democrat Allison Hunter withdrew from the race in December 2007, arguing that Bruce's appointment by a vacancy committee gave him "too great an advantage" in general election;<ref name="hunter">{{cite news |first=Carlyn Ray |last=Mitchell |title=Dem opens bid for commission seat |url=http://www.gazette.com/articles/hunter_33631___article.html/county_seat.html |work=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=27 February 2008 |accessdate=2008-03-02 }}</ref> Waller will face Democrat Michelle Maksimowicz in November 2008.<ref name="defeats"/>

{{Spanish name|Ñegue|Ndong}}{{multiple issues| {{Expand Spanish|date=July 2018}} {{refimprove|date=August 2018}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox Officeholder | name = Francisco Macías Nguema | image = Francisco Macías Nguema.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = | order = 1st [[Heads of state of Equatorial Guinea|President of Equatorial Guinea]] | term_start = 12 October 1968 | term_end = 3 August 1979 | vicepresident = [[Edmundo Bossio]]
[[Miguel Eyegue]]
[[Bonifacio Nguema Esono Nchama]] | viceprimeminister = | deputy = | president = | primeminister = | predecessor = Spanish colonial rule | successor = [[Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo]] | birth_date = 1 January 1924 | birth_place = Nsegayong, Rio Muni, [[Spanish Guinea]] | death_date = {{death date and age|df=y|1979|09|29|1924|01|1}} | death_place = [[Bioko]], Equatorial Guinea | constituency = | party = [[United National Workers' Party]] (''Partido Único Nacional de Trabajadores'') | spouse = | children = At least 2 daughters and 1 son{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/12/world/asia/fond-recollections-of-dictators-colored-later-by-the-lessons-of-history.html|title=Fond Recollections of Dictators, Colored Later by the Lessons of History|author=Choe Sang-Hun|publisher=New York Times|date=October 11, 2013|accessdate=August 12, 2017}} | profession = | religion = | signature = | footnotes = }} {{History of Equatorial Guinea}} '''Francisco Macías Nguema''' (born '''Mez-m Ngueme'''; [[Africanisation|Africanised]] to '''Masie Nguema Biyogo Ñegue Ndong'''; 1 January 1924 – 29 September 1979) was the first [[President of Equatorial Guinea|President]] of [[Equatorial Guinea]], from 1968 until his [[1979 Equatorial Guinea coup d'état|overthrow]] and subsequent execution in 1979.{{fact|date=August 2018}} ==Early life== Born as Mez-m Ngueme, Macías Nguema was the son of a [[witch doctor]] who allegedly killed his younger brother. He belonged to the country's majority [[Fang people|Fang]] ethnic group.{{fact|date=August 2018}} As a boy of 9, Nguema saw his father punched to death by a Spanish colonial administrator when he tried to use his title of chief to negotiate for better wages for his people. Nguema was orphaned a week later when his mother committed suicide, leaving the boy and 10 siblings to fend for themselves.{{fact|date=August 2018}} ==Early political career== Macías Nguema failed the civil service exam three times.{{cite web |title=The Pariah President: Teodoro Obiang is a brutal dictator responsible for thousands of deaths. So why is he treated like an elder statesman on the world stage? |first=Dan |last=Gardner |date=6 November 2005 |publisher=The Ottawa Citizen (reprint: dangardner.ca) |url=http://www.dangardner.ca/Featnov605.html |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080612161320/http://www.dangardner.ca/Featnov605.html |archivedate = 12 June 2008}} However, he eventually rose to the position of mayor of [[Mongomo]] under the Spanish colonial government, and later served as a member of the territorial parliament. In 1964, he was named deputy prime minister of the autonomous transition government. He ran for president of the soon-to-be independent country against Prime Minister [[Bonifacio Ondó Edu]] on a strongly nationalist platform in [[Equatorial Guinean general election, 1968|1968]]. In what has been the only free election held in the country to date, he defeated Ondó Edu in the runoff and was sworn in as president on 12 October. Ondó Edu briefly went into exile in Gabon, and was officially reported to have committed suicide on 5 March 1969, although Edu has been reported to have actually been executed soon after his return on trumped-up charges of having had been planning a coup.{{cite web|url=http://www.afroarticles.com/article-dashboard/Article/Macias-Nguema--Ruthless-and-bloody-dictator/117291|title=Macias Nguema: Ruthless and bloody dictator|publisher=Afroarticles.com|accessdate=1 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141104035212/http://www.afroarticles.com/article-dashboard/Article/Macias-Nguema--Ruthless-and-bloody-dictator/117291|archivedate=4 November 2014|df=dmy-all}} ==Government== On 7 May 1971, Macías Nguema issued Decree 415, which repealed parts of the 1968 Constitution and granted him "all direct powers of Government and Institutions", including powers formerly held by the legislative and judiciary branches, as well as the cabinet of ministers. On 18 October 1971, Law 1 imposed the death penalty as punishment for threatening the President or the government. Insulting or offending the President or his cabinet was punishable by 30 years in prison. On 14 July 1972, a presidential decree merged all existing political parties into the United National Party (later the United National Workers' Party), with Macías Nguema as [[President for Life]] of both nation and party.{{fact|date=August 2018}} In a plebiscite [[Equatorial Guinean constitutional referendum, 1973|held on 29 July 1973]], the 1968 Constitution was replaced with a new document that gave Macías Nguema absolute power and formally made his party the only one legally permitted in the country. According to official figures, an implausible 99 percent of voters approved the new document. Three months later, [[Equatorial Guinean presidential election, 1973|a fresh "presidential election"]] confirmed Macías Nguema as president for life.{{fact|date=August 2018}} Macías Nguema declared private education subversive, and banned it entirely with Decree 6 on 18 March 1975.{{cite book |url=http://www.opensourceguinea.org/2013/10/artucio-arturo-trial-of-macias-in.html |title=The Trial of Macias in Equatorial Guinea |publisher=International Commission of Jurists |author=Alejandro Artucio |pages= 6–8}} During his presidency, his country was nicknamed "the [[Dachau concentration camp|Dachau]] of Africa".Roberts, Adam. The Wonga Coup, p. 21 He was known to order entire families and villages executed.{{fact|date=August 2018}} Three important pillars of his rule were the United National Workers' Party, the [[Juventud en Marcha con Macías]] militia/youth group, and the [[Esangui]] clan of [[Río Muni]]. The country's instruments of repression (military, presidential bodyguard) were entirely controlled by Macías Nguema's relatives and clan members. The president's paranoid actions included mandating the death of those who wore spectacles,[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/personal-view/3610187/If-you-think-this-ones-bad-you-should-have-seen-his-uncle.html If you think this one's bad you should have seen his uncle] banning use of the word "intellectual" and destroying boats to stop his people fleeing from his rule (fishing was banned).{{cite web |title=Equatorial Guinea Background Info |url=http://www.lonelyplanet.com/worldguide/destinations/africa/equatorial-guinea/essential?a=culture |year=2007 |publisher=Lonely Planet |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070309031011/http://www.lonelyplanet.com/worldguide/destinations/africa/equatorial-guinea/essential?a=culture |archivedate=9 March 2007 |df=dmy-all }} The only road out of the country on the mainland was also mined.Roberts, Adam. The Wonga Coup, p. 20 He Africanised his name to '''Masie Nguema Biyogo Ñegue Ndong''' in 1976 after demanding that the rest of the Equatoguinean population replace their Hispanic names with African names. He also banned Western medicines, stating that they were un-African. Macías Nguema was the centre of an extreme [[cult of personality]], perhaps fueled by his consumption of copious amounts of ''[[bhang]]'' and ''[[iboga]]'', and assigned himself titles such as the "Unique Miracle" and "Grand Master of Education, Science, and Culture". The island of Fernando Pó had its name Africanised after him to Masie Ngueme Biyogo Island; upon his overthrow in 1979, its name was again changed to [[Bioko]]. The capital, Santa Isabel, had its name changed to [[Malabo]]. In 1978, he changed the [[national motto]] to "There is no other God than Macías Nguema".{{cite web |url=http://www.afroarticles.com/article-dashboard/article.php?id=117291 |title=Macias Nguema: Ruthless and bloody dictator |publisher=Afroarticles.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160313200255/http://afroarticles.com/article-dashboard/article.php?id=117291 |archivedate=13 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }} During Macías Nguema's government, the country had neither a development plan nor an accounting system for government funds. After the killing of the governor of the Central Bank, he carried everything that remained in the national treasury to his house in a rural village. On Christmas Eve of 1969 about 150 of his opponents were killed. Soldiers executed them by shooting at the football stadium in [[Malabo]], while amplifiers were playing [[Mary Hopkin]]'s song "[[Those Were the Days (song)|Those Were the Days]]."{{cite book|author=Suzanne Cronjé|title=Equatorial Guinea, the forgotten dictatorship: forced labour and political murder in central Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?redir_esc=y&id=8GN0AAAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=christmas|year=1976|publisher=Anti-Slavery Society|isbn=978-0-900918-05-6}} Macías Nguema's government forced tens of thousands of citizens to flee in fear of persecution and to protect their personal safety. Intellectuals and skilled professionals were a particular target, due to which human rights researcher Robert af Klinteberg, in a 1978 study that examined the government's repression in detail, called it a policy of "deliberate cultural regression." Af Klinteberg reported that as of 1978, at least 101,000 persons, out of a contemporary population that the World Bank estimates totalled 215,284 persons—nearly 47% of the population—had fled the country.[https://www.scribd.com/document/87904103/Equatorial-Guinea-macias-Country-klinteberg Robert af Klinteberg, "Equatorial Guinea--Macias Country: The Forgotten Refugees," Geneva, International University Exchange Fund, 1978.][http://data.worldbank.org/country/equatorial-guinea World Bank, "Equatorial Guinea," World Development Indicators; see download file.] Other reporting, such as a 1979 Time magazine account stating that "perhaps 150,000" persons fled, suggests that the proportion of the population that sought safety in exile may have approached 70%, based on the World Bank's estimate of the population in 1979.{{cite news |title=Despot's Fall |date=20 August 1979 |work=TIME Magazine |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,947351,00.html?promoid=googlep}} By the end of his rule, nearly all of the country's educated class was either executed or forced into exile—a [[brain drain]] from which the country has never recovered. Two-thirds of the legislature and 10 of his original ministers were also killed.{{cite book |title=The World Today Series: Africa 2012|last=Dickovick |first=J. Tyler |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2008 |publisher=Stryker-Post Publications |location=Lanham, Maryland |ISBN=978-1-61048-881-5}} Some observers have posited that Macías Nguema may have been a [[Psychopathy|psychopath]], a disorder potentially enabled, in part, by reported childhood [[psychological trauma]], and that his behaviour could have been affected by other possible mental illnesses, as well as his reported periodic use of the psychoactive plant [[Tabernanthe_iboga|Iboga]] and large quantities of [[Cannabis_(drug)|cannabis]].[http://www.hofstra.edu/pdf/community/culctr/culctr_guinea040209_ivbcasavis.pdf David Casavis, “Teasing Out Psychopathic Behaviors of African Leaders: Francisco Macías”], conference paper presented at "[http://www.hofstra.edu/community/culctr/culctr_events_equatorial_guinea.html Between Three Continents: Rethinking Equatorial Guinea on the Fortieth Anniversary of its Independence from Spain]," 2009, at Hofstra University's Cultural Center.Rene Pelissier, "Equatorial Guinea: Autopsy of a Miracle," Africa Report, Vol. 25, No. 3, May-June 1980. ==Overthrow== By 1979, Macías Nguema's government had garnered condemnations from the [[United Nations]] and [[European Commission]]. That summer, Macías Nguema organised the execution of several members of his own family, leading several members of his inner circle to fear that he was no longer acting rationally. On 3 August 1979 he was overthrown by [[Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo]], who was Macías Nguema's nephew (and the brother of one of the victims) and who served previously as the military governor of [[Bioko]] and Vice-Minister of the Armed Forces. The deposed ruler and a contingent of loyal forces initially resisted the coup, but his forces eventually abandoned him, and he was captured in a forest on 18 August.{{cite book |url=http://www.opensourceguinea.org/2013/10/artucio-arturo-trial-of-macias-in.html |title=The Trial of Macias in Equatorial Guinea |publisher=International Commission of Jurists |author=Alejandro Artucio |page= 20}} Prior to his overthrow, he sent his three minor children (Monica, Maribel, and Paco) to [[North Korea]] for safety. They lived there for the remainder of their childhood and now live in various other countries. ==Trial and execution== The Supreme Military Council opened Case 1/979 on 18 August 1979, and began interviewing witnesses and collecting evidence against the Macías Nguema government. The Council subsequently convened a [[military tribunal]] on 24 September to try Macías Nguema and several members of his government. The charges for the ten [[defendant]]s included [[genocide]], [[mass murder]], [[embezzlement]] of public funds, violations of human rights, and [[treason]].{{cite book |url=http://www.opensourceguinea.org/2013/10/artucio-arturo-trial-of-macias-in.html |title=The Trial of Macias in Equatorial Guinea |publisher=International Commission of Jurists |author=Alejandro Artucio |pages= 20–27}} The state prosecutor requested that Macías Nguema receive the [[Capital punishment|death penalty]], five others receive thirty years in prison, and four others receive a year in prison. Macías Nguema's defence counsel countered that the other co-defendants were responsible for specific crimes, and asked for acquittal. Macías Nguema himself delivered a statement to the court outlining what he viewed as the extensive good deeds he had performed for the country. At noon on 29 September 1979, the Tribunal delivered its sentences, which were more severe than what the prosecution had requested. Macías Nguema and six of his co-defendants were sentenced to death and the confiscation of their property; Nguema being sentenced to death '101 times'.{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/teodoro-obiang-nguema-a-brutal-bizarre-jailer-448575.html |location=London |work=The Independent | first=Steve | last=Bloomfield | title=Teodoro Obiang Nguema: A brutal, bizarre jailer | date=13 May 2007}} Two defendants were sentenced to fourteen years in prison each, and two others to four years each.{{cite book |title=The Trial of Macias in Equatorial Guinea |publisher=International Commission of Jurists |author=Alejandro Artucio |pages= 52–55}} With no higher court available to hear appeals, the decision of the Special Military Tribunal was final. Macías Nguema and the six other defendants sentenced to death were executed by a hired [[Moroccan Army]] firing squad at [[Black Beach Prison]] at 6 pm on the same day.{{cite book |url=http://www.opensourceguinea.org/2013/10/artucio-arturo-trial-of-macias-in.html |title=The Trial of Macias in Equatorial Guinea |publisher=International Commission of Jurists |author=Alejandro Artucio |pages= 54–55}}John B. Quigley (2006) ''The Genocide Convention: An International Law Analysis'', Ashgate Publishing, Ltd, {{ISBN|0-7546-4730-7}}. [https://books.google.com/books?id=ZXZ8qMR5YVQC&pg=PA31&lpg=PA31&source=web&ots=zIfJ7DEYzK&sig=lDM-pfUAVB_cC6Mu7k4pCvqOUx0 p.31], 32Max Liniger-Goumaz (1988) ''Small is Not Always Beautiful: The Story of Equatorial Guinea'', C. Hurst and Company, {{ISBN|1-85065-023-3}}. p.64 During his execution, he was reportedly "calm and dignified".Adam Roberts, ''The Wonga Coup'' (2006), p. 40. Depending on the source, during his government, anywhere from 50,000 to 80,000 of the 300,000 to 400,000 people living in the country at the time were killed. According to [[Pennsylvania State University]] professor Randall Fegley, this was proportionally worse than the Nazis' rampage through Europe. He has been compared to [[Pol Pot]] because of the violent, unpredictable, and anti-intellectual nature of his government. ==References== {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box|title=[[President of Equatorial Guinea]]|before=(Spanish Colonial Rule/[[Indigenous peoples of Africa|Indigenous]] Tribal Rule)|after=[[Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo]]|years=1968–1979}} {{s-end}} {{EquatoguineanPresidents}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nguema, Francisco Macias}} [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:1979 deaths]] [[Category:Deified people]] [[Category:Mongomo]] [[Category:Leaders ousted by a coup]] [[Category:Executed presidents]] [[Category:20th-century executions by Equatorial Guinea]] [[Category:People executed by Equatorial Guinea by firing squad]] [[Category:Executed Equatoguinean people]] [[Category:Equatoguinean people convicted of murder]] [[Category:Equatoguinean people convicted of genocide]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by Equatorial Guinea]] [[Category:Presidents for life]] [[Category:Presidents of Equatorial Guinea]] [[Category:People from Río Muni]]

{{Infobox Officeholder |name = Grigori N. Voitinsky
Григорий Наумович Войтинский |image = G.N. Voitrngsky.jpg |image_size = |caption = |birth_name=Grigori Zarkhin |birth_date = 17 April 1893 |birth_place = [[Nevel (town)|Nevel]] |death_date = 11 June 1953 |death_place = [[Moscow]] |occupation = |order = Head of the Far Eastern Bureau |term_start = |term_end = |premier = [[Vladimir Lenin]] |predecessor = |successor = |party = [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] (CPSU) |spouse = |relations = }} '''Grigori Naumovich Voitinsky''', born '''Zarkhin''' ({{Lang-ru|Григорий Наумович Войтинский}}; 1893-1953) A Bolshevik [[Comintern]] Official. He was sent to [[China]] in 1920 as an Senior advisor to contact the Top prominent Chinese Communists such as [[Chen Duxiu]], just before the formation of the [[Communist Party of China]]. The process of forming the Communist Party can be mostly attributed to his influence, although his successor advisors had more influence about the official Party line itself, such as allying with the [[Guomindang]]. He was born on 17 April 1893 in [[Nevel (town)|Nevel]] to a Russian Jewish Family. In 1918, he joined the Bolshevik Party. He took an active part in the [[Far Eastern Front in the Russian Civil War]].Yoshihiro Ishikawa, ''The Formation of the Chinese Communist Party''. Columbia University Press, 2013 == Work in China == In 1920, the [[Soviet Union]] established the Far Eastern Bureau in [[Siberia]], a branch of the Third Communist International, or the [[Comintern]]. He was directly responsible for managing the establishment of a Communist party in China and other far east countries. Soon after its establishment, the bureau's deputy manager Voitinsky arrived in [[Beijing]] and contacted the Communist vanguard [[Li Dazhao]]. Li arranged for Voitinsky to meet with another Communist leader, [[Chen Duxiu]], in [[Shanghai]]. In August 1920, Voitinsky, Chen Duxiu, [[Li Hanjun]], [[Shen Xuanlu]], [[Yu Xiusong]], [[Shi Cuntong]], and others began to establish the Comintern China Branch. The ''[[Shanghai Chronicle]]'' was set up in 1919 in Shanghai by [[Shemeshko]] and other Russians with [[socialism|socialist]] leanings, and received financial aid from the Soviet Russian government in early 1920. In the spring of 1920, Voitinsky and his colleagues came to China on a mission to establish the Communist Party in China. They not only came to China in the guise of editors and reporters for the newspaper, but also set up the Comintern's East Asia Secretariat in the newspaper office. From then on, the ''Shanghai Chronicle'' became both a propaganda vehicle for the East Asia Secretariat and a cover for [[Bolshevik]] activity in China. Because the newspaper staff assisted Soviet Russian and Comintern personnel stationed under cover at the newspaper in activities to establish a communist organization in China, the newspaper as a whole played a special role in the early communist movement in China. Although the ''Shanghai Chronicle'' stopped publication at the end of 1922 because Russian aid came to an end, many staff members continued to work for Bolshevism.Frank L. Britton ''Behind Communism''. University of Michigan, 1952 == Later career == He worked as Comintern representative until 1926. Then worked in the Siberian government in [[Irkutsk]] until 1929, when he moved to Moscow, where he worked in various orientalist institutions. In 1934 he became a professor in [[Moscow State University]].[http://www.pseudology.org/Bolsheviki_lenintsy/Voitinsky_Zaxrin.htm]| Biography (in Russian) He is considered one of the founders of Soviet [[Sinology]]. He wrote several books about contemporary China politics. He died in 1953 during an unsuccessful surgical operation. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Voitinsky}} [[Category:1893 births]] [[Category:1956 deaths]] [[Category:Communist Party of the Soviet Union members]] [[Category:Comintern people]] [[Category:Soviet Jews]] {{Russia-bio-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Use British English|date=May 2015}} '''Henry Robert "Bob" Holmes''' (11 May 1895<ref name=bate>Bateman, Robert. ''Stamp collectors' who's who''. London: [[Stanley Gibbons]], 1960, p. 46.</ref> – 22 January 1989<ref>"Henry Robert Holmes - Distinguished Past President" by A. Ronald Butler in [[The London Philatelist]], March–April 1989, No. 1155-56, Vol. 98, pp. 37-38.</ref>) was President of the [[Royal Philatelic Society London]] 1961-64 and signed the [[Roll of Distinguished Philatelists]] in 1953.<ref name=abps>[http://www.abps.org.uk/Home/Who_Was_Who/index.xalter#H Who Was Who in British Philately.] [[Association of British Philatelic Societies]] 2010. Retrieved 19 December 2011.</ref>
From 1947 Holmes was an Honorary Curator of the philatelic collections at the British Museum, now constituted as the [[British Library Philatelic Collections]]. He was an expert on the stamps of Bermuda and Bechuanaland, and a corresponding member of L'Académie de Philatélie. His papers on the postage stamps of Griqualand West 1877 and the provisional issue of the Republic of Honduras were reprinted from [[The London Philatelist]], of which he was also the editor July 1946 to December 1954.<ref>"Editorship of the London Philatelist" by Frank Walton in ''The London Philatelist'', No. 1287, July–August 2001, Vol. 110, p. 182.</ref>
He won a silver medal at the ''Jubilee International Exhibition 1912'', the ''Brandt Prize'' in 1941 and the [[Lichtenstein Medal]] in 1969.
==Selected publications== *''The Postage Stamps of Bermuda''. 1932. *''Stamps of the Private Byposts of Norway''. 1938. * ''The Postage Stamps of Tibet''. 1941. * ''The Postage Stamps, Postal Stationery, and Postmarks of the Bechuanalands.'' Royal Philatelic Society London, 1971.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * ''H. R. Holmes Collection, The Bechuanalands.'' Auction catalogue, Sale 4327, Harmers of London (29 October 1981).
